While, in the regression model, 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i} is the value vector of features, and yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is the ground-truth label. f​(𝐱i)𝑓subscript𝐱𝑖f(\mathbf{x}_{i}) is the predicted value of this model.

S2.T2.caption: TABLE II: List of loss functions
references: where the notations are defined in Table I,111Note that a bold lowercase letter denotes a vector, ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| denotes the Euclidean norm of a vector, 𝔼​(⋅)𝔼⋅\mathbb{E}(\cdot) denotes a mathematical expectation of variable and ℙ​(⋅)ℙ⋅\mathbb{P}(\cdot) denotes the probability of event. and some examples of loss functions are provided in Table II.222In the classification model, y𝑦y and p𝑝p denote the ground-truth label of a sample and the probability that this model predicts it correctly. While, in the regression model, 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i} is the value vector of features, and yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is the ground-truth label. f​(𝐱i)𝑓subscript𝐱𝑖f(\mathbf{x}_{i}) is the predicted value of this model.

It is indicated that F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰{F}(\mathbf{w}) cannot
be calculated directly by following Table II due to the lack of users’ data at the BS. Instead, we refer to (5) for computing F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰{F}(\mathbf{w}) after global aggregation.

A proportion of loss functions are shown in Table II satisfying 1)-3) in Assumption 1. These loss functions are often used in some classification models and regression models, such as support vector machine (SVM), convolutional neural network (CNN), and linear regression, which will be examined later in our simulations in Section V. Regarding 4) of Assumption 1, gradient divergence reflects the difference among data distributions of all the users. If the data distributions are similar to each other, the gradient divergence will be small, and vice versa. Furthermore, 5) of Assumption 1 reflects the difference between model trained by FL and that trained by centralized machine learning.

references: 1) Parameters: For our simulations, we consider an FL system with five users and one BS. For simplicity of illustration, we run simulations to compute the average time delay of local training and communication/aggregation. To be specific, we have tc​m=0.14subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚0.14t_{cm}=0.14s in the SVM model, and tc​m=0.143subscript𝑡𝑐𝑚0.143t_{cm}=0.143s in the CNN model. Because CNN has more parameters than SVM, it has a larger Z​(𝐰)𝑍𝐰Z(\mathbf{w}). Thus its tc​msubscript𝑡𝑐𝑚t_{cm} longer is realistic. The other parameters used in the simulations are listed in Table III.

To reflect the lower convergence speed in the case of non-i.i.d. data for model training, we set a lower value of ∇F∗∇superscript𝐹
abla F^{*} in the simulation. In general, the CNN model has more parameters than the SVM model, so we set a larger value of ∇F∗∇superscript𝐹
abla F^{*} in CNN. Finally, in the same model, training on a larger dataset makes the value of ∇F∗∇superscript𝐹
abla F^{*} larger. We summarize ∇F∗∇superscript𝐹
abla F^{*} in different cases in Table IV.

S5.T5.caption: TABLE V: τ∗superscript𝜏\tau^{*} in different cases
S5.T5.table:
Case τ∗superscript𝜏\tau^{*}
SVM + i.i.d. + MNIST 17
SVM + non-i.i.d. + MNIST 10
CNN + i.i.d. + MNIST 20
CNN + non-i.i.d. + MNIST 17
CNN + i.i.d. + CIFAR-10 20
CNN + non-i.i.d. + CIFAR-10 13
references: We see that in different cases with the i.i.d. dataset, as τ𝜏\tau increases, the loss value decreases and predict accuracy improves. In the CNN model, the optimal τ𝜏\tau is large and close to 100100100 while close to 202020 in the SVM model. However, we see the loss value of CNN is stable when τ𝜏\tau is more than 202020. Therefore, to avoid overfitting, we set τm​a​xsubscript𝜏𝑚𝑎𝑥\tau_{max} to be 202020. In the non-i.i.d. dataset, the curves for the loss value represent a “U” shape. The optimal τ𝜏\tau’s are close to 101010, which is consistent with the analysis in Theorem 222. It indicates that training model with the non-i.i.d. data need more aggregations (e.g. a lower τ𝜏\tau). With the parameters setup in our simulations, the theoretical optimal τ𝜏\tau’s in different cases are shown in Table V, which almost coincide with the numerical results in Fig. 1.

In the third part of our simulations, we compare the proposed algorithm with the baseline from [32], where the optimal τ𝜏\tau is given in Table V. Specifically, the following three categories of comparisons are considered, and their corresponding results are presented in Figs. 3-5.
